annotation_sentence: Sure, sure. On Eid, we... um, we meet family. We eat much food!
rationale: The word 'much' is a quantifier used to indicate a large amount of food.

annotation_sentence: Yes, before Eid, we have Ramadan. We fast for whole month.
rationale: The word 'whole' is a quantifier referring to the complete duration of the month.

annotation_sentence: When I was small. My family visit village. All cousins play together.
rationale: The word 'all' is a quantifier used to indicate that every cousin plays together.

annotation_sentence: Yes, I think... um, kheer. It is like sweet rice pudding. I love it very much.
rationale: The phrase 'very much' is a quantifier expressing a large degree of fondness.

annotation_sentence: We eat much food! Sweet dishes, like... like sheer khurma.
rationale: 'Much' is a quantifier used to describe an uncountable amount of food.
'Whole' is a quantifier used to describe an entire single unit (month) of time.
'All' is a quantifier used to describe the totality of a group (cousins).

annotation_sentence: Yes, uh, when I was small.
rationale: 'Small' is used here in a context that refers to a young age or little size, indirectly quantifying the speaker's age at that time.
'Every' is a quantifier used to describe each single unit (year) in a series.

annotation_sentence: It is rice with spices and chicken.
rationale: While 'rice', 'spices', and 'chicken' are not directly quantifiers, they refer to uncountable nouns that likely require quantification in context.
